The USGS Visual Identity System Guidance webpage ("Acknowledging or Crediting USGS as Information Source") provides additional details:  https://www2.usgs.gov/visual-id/credit_usgs.html.</datacred><secinfo><secsys>None</secsys><secclass>Unclassified</secclass><sechandl>None</sechandl></secinfo><native>Oracle</native><crossref><citeinfo><origin>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</origin><pubdate>20060510</pubdate><title>Landsat 8 OLI/TIRS Collection 1</title><geoform>Remote-Sensing Image</geoform><pubinfo><pubplace>Sioux Falls, South Dakota, USA</pubplace><publish>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</publish></pubinfo><onlink>https://earthexplorer.usgs.gov</onlink></citeinfo></crossref></idinfo><dataqual><attracc><attraccr>The identification of features is provided by the distinct electromagnetic energy it emits, reflects, or otherwise transmits, this is called the spectral signature.  Other signatures such as tone (lightness or darkness), texture (surface roughness or smoothness), pattern, shadow, shape, and size are just as important.  Thus, through the use of the Operational Land Imager (OLI)  sensor, such elements as water features, soils, and vegetation can be identified and distinguished from each other.</attraccr></attracc><logic>N/A</logic><complete>The Landsat satellites circle the Earth on a sun-synchronous, near-polar orbit imaging the same 185 km (115 miles) ground swath every 16 days.</complete><posacc><horizpa><horizpar>L8 Level-1 systematic products meet the system requirement of 65 meters at a circular error with 90 percent confidence (CE90) horizontal accuracy.</horizpar></horizpa></posacc><lineage><procstep><procdesc>Landsat standard data products are processed using the Level-1 Product Generation System (LPGS), and are processed to the best level of correction possible (Level-1TP = Precision Terrain correction).  If full terrain correction is not possible, the data is processed to Level-1GS (Systematic) or Level-1GT (Systematic Terrain) correction.  Processing details can be found on http://landsat.usgs.gov/landsat-processing-details.  All Landsat 8 Level-1 Collection 1 data have been reprocessed and organized by a tiered inventory structure.  During Collection 1 reprocessing, all Landsat scenes in the USGS archive are assigned to a specific "Tier" based on data quality and level of processing.  If Tier 1 correction is not possible, the data is assigned to Tier 2.  Processing details can be found at https://landsat.usgs.gov/landsat-collections.</procdesc><procdate>20161030</procdate><proccont><cntinfo><grouping><cntperp><cntper>custserv@usgs.gov</cntper><cntorg>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</cntorg></cntperp></grouping><cntpos>Customer Service Representative</cntpos><cntaddr><addrtype>Mailing and Physical Address</addrtype><address>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center 47914 252nd Street</address><city>Sioux Falls</city><state>SD</state><postal>57198-0001</postal><country>USA</country></cntaddr><cntemail>custserv@usgs.gov</cntemail><hours>0800 - 1600 CT, M - F, -6 GMT</hours><cntinst>custserv@usgs.gov</cntinst></cntinfo></proccont></procstep></lineage><cloud></cloud></dataqual><spdoinfo><indspref>Landsat 8 collects data at 30-meter resolution (Panchromatic band 8 at 15 meters; thermal at 100 meters) </indspref><grouping><direct>Raster</direct><grouping><rastinfo><rasttype>Pixel</rasttype></rastinfo></grouping></grouping></spdoinfo><distinfo><grouping><distrib><cntinfo><grouping><cntperp><cntper>custserv@usgs.gov</cntper><cntorg>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</cntorg></cntperp></grouping><cntpos>Customer Service Representative</cntpos><cntaddr><addrtype>Mailing and Physical Address</addrtype><address>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center 47914 252nd Street</address><city>Sioux Falls</city><state>SD</state><postal>57198-0001</postal><country>USA</country></cntaddr><cntemail>custserv@usgs.gov</cntemail><hours>0800 - 1600 CT, M-F, -6 h GMT</hours><cntinst>custserv@usgs.gov</cntinst></cntinfo></distrib><distliab>Although these data have been processed successfully on a computer system at the USGS, no warranty expressed or implied is made by the USGS regarding the use of the data on any other system, nor does the act of distribution constitute any such warranty.</distliab><stdorder><grouping><digform><digtinfo><formname>Geographcal-Tagged Image File Format (GeoTIFF), or Joint Photographic Experts Group (JPEG)</formname></digtinfo><digtopt><grouping><onlinopt><computer><grouping><networka><networkr>https://glovis.usgs.gov</networkr><networkr>https://earthexplorer.usgs.gov</networkr></networka></grouping></computer></onlinopt></grouping></digtopt></digform></grouping><fees>All Landsat data held in the USGS EROS archive are downloadable at no cost to all users.</fees><ordering>You may DOWNLOAD Landsat data online using EarthExplorer at http://earthexplorer.usgs.gov </ordering></stdorder><techpreq>Adequate computer capability is the only technical prerequisite for viewing data in digital form.&#xD;

<fgdc><metadata><idinfo><citation><citeinfo><origin>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</origin><pubdate>2013</pubdate><title>LANDSAT 8 OLI/TIRS Collection 1 - Path:  177 Row:  29 for Scene:  LC08_L1GT_177029_20170125_20170311_01_T2</title><geoform>Remote-Sensing Image</geoform><pubinfo><pubplace>Sioux Falls, South Dakota, USA</pubplace><publish>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</publish></pubinfo><onlink>https://lta.cr.usgs.gov/L8</onlink></citeinfo></citation><descript><abstract>The USGS Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center archive holds data collected by the Landsat suite of satellites, beginning with Landsat 1 in 1972.  Landsat 8, launched February 11, 2013, is the latest Landsat sensor.</abstract><purpose>The Landsat archive provides a rich collection of information about the Earth's land surface.  Major characteristics of changes to the surface of the planet can be detected, measured, and analyzed using Landsat data.  The information obtainable from the historical and current Landsat data play a key role in studying surface changes through time.</purpose><supplinf>Landsat represents the world's longest continuously acquired collection of space-based moderate-resolution land remote sensing data.  As a joint initiative between the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) and the National Aeronautical Space Administration (NASA), the Landsat Project and the data it collects support government, commercial, industrial, civilian, military, and educational communities throughout the United States and world.  Landsat 8 Operational Land Imager (OLI)/Thermal Infrared Sensor (TIRS) Collection 1 provides a quality-controlled selection of radiometrically calibrated and consistently geolocated data; particular geodetic accuracy and error tolerances are specified to align pixels for time series analysis through the full Landsat record. (https://landsat.usgs.gov/landsat-collections)</supplinf></descript><timeperd><timeinfo><grouping><sngdate><caldate>20170125</caldate></sngdate><rngdates><begdate>Start of &#xD;
There are no restrictions regarding the use of Landsat data distributed by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), unless expressly identified prior to or at the time of receipt. For Landsat, we request the following statement be used: Data available from the U.S. Geological Survey. Please refer to https://lta.cr.usgs.gov/ee_help_data_citation for more information on data citation.&#xD;
</useconst><ptcontac><cntinfo><grouping><cntperp><cntper>custserv@usgs.gov</cntper><cntorg>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</cntorg></cntperp></grouping><cntpos>Customer Service Representative</cntpos><cntaddr><addrtype>Mailing and Physical Address</addrtype><address>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center 47914 252nd Street</address><city>Sioux Falls</city><state>SD</state><postal>57198-0001</postal><country>USA</country></cntaddr><cntemail>custserv@usgs.gov</cntemail><hours>0800 - 1600 CT, M-F, -6 h GMT</hours><cntinst>custserv@usgs.gov</cntinst></cntinfo></ptcontac><browse><browsen>Browse graphic for:  http://earthexplorer.usgs.gov/browse/landsat_8/browse/full/landsat_8/LC08_L1GT_177029_20170125_20170311_01_T2</browsen><browsed>This is a compressed and resampled version of the Landsat image to help validate area of interest, data quality, and the impact of cloud cover, if it exists.</browsed><browset>JPEG</browset></browse><datacred>The Landsat Program, as defined by Congress in 1992 and amended by Presidential Decision Directive/NSTC-3 in May 1994, is managed cooperatively by the NASA and the USGS.  Responsibility for construction of the spacecraft and instrument lies with NASA.  The Landsat Program is part of NASA's Earth Observing System, a global change initiative administered by NASA's Earth Science Enterprise.  Data processing, archiving, and distribution are performed by the USGS.  The primary ground station, the data handling facility and archive are located at the USGS Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center in Sioux Falls, SD.  NASA managed flight operations from the control center at the Goddard Space Flight Center until October 1, 2000, at which time responsibility for flight operations transferred to the USGS.  The ground system is able to distribute Landsat 8 OLI/TIR data within 24 hours of its reception at the EROS.  The following statement should be used when citing, copying, or reprinting Landsat imagery or data: Data available from the U.S. Geological Survey.  The USGS Visual Identity System Guidance webpage ("Acknowledging or Crediting USGS as Information Source") provides additional details:  https://www2.usgs.gov/visual-id/credit_usgs.html.</datacred><secinfo><secsys>None</secsys><secclass>Unclassified</secclass><sechandl>None</sechandl></secinfo><native>Oracle</native><crossref><citeinfo><origin>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</origin><pubdate>20060510</pubdate><title>Landsat 8 OLI/TIRS Collection 1</title><geoform>Remote-Sensing Image</geoform><pubinfo><pubplace>Sioux Falls, South Dakota, USA</pubplace><publish>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</publish></pubinfo><onlink>https://earthexplorer.usgs.gov</onlink></citeinfo></crossref></idinfo><dataqual><attracc><attraccr>The identification of features is provided by the distinct electromagnetic energy it emits, reflects, or otherwise transmits, this is called the spectral signature. The USGS Visual Identity System Guidance webpage ("Acknowledging or Crediting USGS as Information Source") provides additional details:  https://www2.usgs.gov/visual-id/credit_usgs.html.</datacred><secinfo><secsys>None</secsys><secclass>Unclassified</secclass><sechandl>None</sechandl></secinfo><native>Oracle</native><crossref><citeinfo><origin>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</origin><pubdate>20060510</pubdate><title>Landsat 8 OLI/TIRS Collection 1</title><geoform>Remote-Sensing Image</geoform><pubinfo><pubplace>Sioux Falls, South Dakota, USA</pubplace><publish>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</publish></pubinfo><onlink>https://earthexplorer.usgs.gov</onlink></citeinfo></crossref></idinfo><dataqual><attracc><attraccr>The identification of features is provided by the distinct electromagnetic energy it emits, reflects, or otherwise transmits, this is called the spectral signature.  Other signatures such as tone (lightness or darkness), texture (surface roughness or smoothness), pattern, shadow, shape, and size are just as important.  Thus, through the use of the Operational Land Imager (OLI)  sensor, such elements as water features, soils, and vegetation can be identified and distinguished from each other.</attraccr></attracc><logic>N/A</logic><complete>The Landsat satellites circle the Earth on a sun-synchronous, near-polar orbit imaging the same 185 km (115 miles) ground swath every 16 days.</complete><posacc><horizpa><horizpar>L8 Level-1 systematic products meet the system requirement of 65 meters at a circular error with 90 percent confidence (CE90) horizontal accuracy.</horizpar></horizpa></posacc><lineage><procstep><procdesc>Landsat standard data products are processed using the Level-1 Product Generation System (LPGS), and are processed to the best level of correction possible (Level-1TP = Precision Terrain correction).  If full terrain correction is not possible, the data is processed to Level-1GS (Systematic) or Level-1GT (Systematic Terrain) correction.  Processing details can be found on http://landsat.usgs.gov/landsat-processing-details.  All Landsat 8 Level-1 Collection 1 data have been reprocessed and organized by a tiered inventory structure.  During Collection 1 reprocessing, all Landsat scenes in the USGS archive are assigned to a specific "Tier" based on data quality and level of processing.  If Tier 1 correction is not possible, the data is assigned to Tier 2.  Processing details can be found at https://landsat.usgs.gov/landsat-collections.</procdesc><procdate>20161030</procdate><proccont><cntinfo><grouping><cntperp><cntper>custserv@usgs.gov</cntper><cntorg>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</cntorg></cntperp></grouping><cntpos>Customer Service Representative</cntpos><cntaddr><addrtype>Mailing and Physical Address</addrtype><address>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center 47914 252nd Street</address><city>Sioux Falls</city><state>SD</state><postal>57198-0001</postal><country>USA</country></cntaddr><cntemail>custserv@usgs.gov</cntemail><hours>0800 - 1600 CT, M - F, -6 GMT</hours><cntinst>custserv@usgs.gov</cntinst></cntinfo></proccont></procstep></lineage><cloud></cloud></dataqual><spdoinfo><indspref>Landsat 8 collects data at 30-meter resolution (Panchromatic band 8 at 15 meters; thermal at 100 meters) </indspref><grouping><direct>Raster</direct><grouping><rastinfo><rasttype>Pixel</rasttype></rastinfo></grouping></grouping></spdoinfo><distinfo><grouping><distrib><cntinfo><grouping><cntperp><cntper>custserv@usgs.gov</cntper><cntorg>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</cntorg></cntperp></grouping><cntpos>Customer Service Representative</cntpos><cntaddr><addrtype>Mailing and Physical Address</addrtype><address>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center 47914 252nd Street</address><city>Sioux Falls</city><state>SD</state><postal>57198-0001</postal><country>USA</country></cntaddr><cntemail>custserv@usgs.gov</cntemail><hours>0800 - 1600 CT, M-F, -6 h GMT</hours><cntinst>custserv@usgs.gov</cntinst></cntinfo></distrib><distliab>Although these data have been processed successfully on a computer system at the USGS, no warranty expressed or implied is made by the USGS regarding the use of the data on any other system, nor does the act of distribution constitute any such warranty.</distliab><stdorder><grouping><digform><digtinfo><formname>Geographcal-Tagged Image File Format (GeoTIFF), or Joint Photographic Experts Group (JPEG)</formname></digtinfo><digtopt><grouping><onlinopt><computer><grouping><networka><networkr>https://glovis.usgs.gov</networkr><networkr>https://earthexplorer.usgs.gov</networkr></networka></grouping></computer></onlinopt></grouping></digtopt></digform></grouping><fees>All Landsat data held in the USGS EROS archive are downloadable at no cost to all users.</fees><ordering>You may DOWNLOAD Landsat data online using EarthExplorer at http://earthexplorer.usgs.gov </ordering></stdorder><techpreq>Adequate computer capability is the only technical prerequisite for viewing data in digital form.&#xD;

<fgdc><metadata><idinfo><citation><citeinfo><origin>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</origin><pubdate>2013</pubdate><title>LANDSAT 8 OLI/TIRS Collection 1 - Path:  178 Row:  28 for Scene:  LC08_L1TP_178028_20170116_20170311_01_T1</title><geoform>Remote-Sensing Image</geoform><pubinfo><pubplace>Sioux Falls, South Dakota, USA</pubplace><publish>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</publish></pubinfo><onlink>https://lta.cr.usgs.gov/L8</onlink></citeinfo></citation><descript><abstract>The USGS Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center archive holds data collected by the Landsat suite of satellites, beginning with Landsat 1 in 1972.  Landsat 8, launched February 11, 2013, is the latest Landsat sensor.</abstract><purpose>The Landsat archive provides a rich collection of information about the Earth's land surface.  Major characteristics of changes to the surface of the planet can be detected, measured, and analyzed using Landsat data.  The information obtainable from the historical and current Landsat data play a key role in studying surface changes through time.</purpose><supplinf>Landsat represents the world's longest continuously acquired collection of space-based moderate-resolution land remote sensing data.  As a joint initiative between the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) and the National Aeronautical Space Administration (NASA), the Landsat Project and the data it collects support government, commercial, industrial, civilian, military, and educational communities throughout the United States and world.  Landsat 8 Operational Land Imager (OLI)/Thermal Infrared Sensor (TIRS) Collection 1 provides a quality-controlled selection of radiometrically calibrated and consistently geolocated data; particular geodetic accuracy and error tolerances are specified to align pixels for time series analysis through the full Landsat record. (https://landsat.usgs.gov/landsat-collections)</supplinf></descript><timeperd><timeinfo><grouping><sngdate><caldate>20170116</caldate></sngdate><rngdates><begdate>Start of &#xD;
There are no restrictions regarding the use of Landsat data distributed by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), unless expressly identified prior to or at the time of receipt. For Landsat, we request the following statement be used: Data available from the U.S. Geological Survey. Please refer to https://lta.cr.usgs.gov/ee_help_data_citation for more information on data citation.&#xD;
</useconst><ptcontac><cntinfo><grouping><cntperp><cntper>custserv@usgs.gov</cntper><cntorg>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</cntorg></cntperp></grouping><cntpos>Customer Service Representative</cntpos><cntaddr><addrtype>Mailing and Physical Address</addrtype><address>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center 47914 252nd Street</address><city>Sioux Falls</city><state>SD</state><postal>57198-0001</postal><country>USA</country></cntaddr><cntemail>custserv@usgs.gov</cntemail><hours>0800 - 1600 CT, M-F, -6 h GMT</hours><cntinst>custserv@usgs.gov</cntinst></cntinfo></ptcontac><browse><browsen>Browse graphic for:  http://earthexplorer.usgs.gov/browse/landsat_8/browse/full/landsat_8/LC08_L1TP_178028_20170116_20170311_01_T1</browsen><browsed>This is a compressed and resampled version of the Landsat image to help validate area of interest, data quality, and the impact of cloud cover, if it exists.</browsed><browset>JPEG</browset></browse><datacred>The Landsat Program, as defined by Congress in 1992 and amended by Presidential Decision Directive/NSTC-3 in May 1994, is managed cooperatively by the NASA and the USGS.  Responsibility for construction of the spacecraft and instrument lies with NASA.  The Landsat Program is part of NASA's Earth Observing System, a global change initiative administered by NASA's Earth Science Enterprise.  Data processing, archiving, and distribution are performed by the USGS.  The primary ground station, the data handling facility and archive are located at the USGS Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center in Sioux Falls, SD.  NASA managed flight operations from the control center at the Goddard Space Flight Center until October 1, 2000, at which time responsibility for flight operations transferred to the USGS.  The ground system is able to distribute Landsat 8 OLI/TIR data within 24 hours of its reception at the EROS.  The following statement should be used when citing, copying, or reprinting Landsat imagery or data: Data available from the U.S. Geological Survey.  The USGS Visual Identity System Guidance webpage ("Acknowledging or Crediting USGS as Information Source") provides additional details:  https://www2.usgs.gov/visual-id/credit_usgs.html.</datacred><secinfo><secsys>None</secsys><secclass>Unclassified</secclass><sechandl>None</sechandl></secinfo><native>Oracle</native><crossref><citeinfo><origin>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</origin><pubdate>20060510</pubdate><title>Landsat 8 OLI/TIRS Collection 1</title><geoform>Remote-Sensing Image</geoform><pubinfo><pubplace>Sioux Falls, South Dakota, USA</pubplace><publish>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</publish></pubinfo><onlink>https://earthexplorer.usgs.gov</onlink></citeinfo></crossref></idinfo><dataqual><attracc><attraccr>The identification of features is provided by the distinct electromagnetic energy it emits, reflects, or otherwise transmits, this is called the spectral signature. The USGS Visual Identity System Guidance webpage ("Acknowledging or Crediting USGS as Information Source") provides additional details:  https://www2.usgs.gov/visual-id/credit_usgs.html.</datacred><secinfo><secsys>None</secsys><secclass>Unclassified</secclass><sechandl>None</sechandl></secinfo><native>Oracle</native><crossref><citeinfo><origin>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</origin><pubdate>20060510</pubdate><title>Landsat 8 OLI/TIRS Collection 1</title><geoform>Remote-Sensing Image</geoform><pubinfo><pubplace>Sioux Falls, South Dakota, USA</pubplace><publish>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</publish></pubinfo><onlink>https://earthexplorer.usgs.gov</onlink></citeinfo></crossref></idinfo><dataqual><attracc><attraccr>The identification of features is provided by the distinct electromagnetic energy it emits, reflects, or otherwise transmits, this is called the spectral signature.  Other signatures such as tone (lightness or darkness), texture (surface roughness or smoothness), pattern, shadow, shape, and size are just as important.  Thus, through the use of the Operational Land Imager (OLI)  sensor, such elements as water features, soils, and vegetation can be identified and distinguished from each other.</attraccr></attracc><logic>N/A</logic><complete>The Landsat satellites circle the Earth on a sun-synchronous, near-polar orbit imaging the same 185 km (115 miles) ground swath every 16 days.</complete><posacc><horizpa><horizpar>L8 Level-1 systematic products meet the system requirement of 65 meters at a circular error with 90 percent confidence (CE90) horizontal accuracy.</horizpar></horizpa></posacc><lineage><procstep><procdesc>Landsat standard data products are processed using the Level-1 Product Generation System (LPGS), and are processed to the best level of correction possible (Level-1TP = Precision Terrain correction).  If full terrain correction is not possible, the data is processed to Level-1GS (Systematic) or Level-1GT (Systematic Terrain) correction.  Processing details can be found on http://landsat.usgs.gov/landsat-processing-details.  All Landsat 8 Level-1 Collection 1 data have been reprocessed and organized by a tiered inventory structure.  During Collection 1 reprocessing, all Landsat scenes in the USGS archive are assigned to a specific "Tier" based on data quality and level of processing.  If Tier 1 correction is not possible, the data is assigned to Tier 2.  Processing details can be found at https://landsat.usgs.gov/landsat-collections.</procdesc><procdate>20161030</procdate><proccont><cntinfo><grouping><cntperp><cntper>custserv@usgs.gov</cntper><cntorg>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</cntorg></cntperp></grouping><cntpos>Customer Service Representative</cntpos><cntaddr><addrtype>Mailing and Physical Address</addrtype><address>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center 47914 252nd Street</address><city>Sioux Falls</city><state>SD</state><postal>57198-0001</postal><country>USA</country></cntaddr><cntemail>custserv@usgs.gov</cntemail><hours>0800 - 1600 CT, M - F, -6 GMT</hours><cntinst>custserv@usgs.gov</cntinst></cntinfo></proccont></procstep></lineage><cloud></cloud></dataqual><spdoinfo><indspref>Landsat 8 collects data at 30-meter resolution (Panchromatic band 8 at 15 meters; thermal at 100 meters) </indspref><grouping><direct>Raster</direct><grouping><rastinfo><rasttype>Pixel</rasttype></rastinfo></grouping></grouping></spdoinfo><distinfo><grouping><distrib><cntinfo><grouping><cntperp><cntper>custserv@usgs.gov</cntper><cntorg>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</cntorg></cntperp></grouping><cntpos>Customer Service Representative</cntpos><cntaddr><addrtype>Mailing and Physical Address</addrtype><address>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center 47914 252nd Street</address><city>Sioux Falls</city><state>SD</state><postal>57198-0001</postal><country>USA</country></cntaddr><cntemail>custserv@usgs.gov</cntemail><hours>0800 - 1600 CT, M-F, -6 h GMT</hours><cntinst>custserv@usgs.gov</cntinst></cntinfo></distrib><distliab>Although these data have been processed successfully on a computer system at the USGS, no warranty expressed or implied is made by the USGS regarding the use of the data on any other system, nor does the act of distribution constitute any such warranty.</distliab><stdorder><grouping><digform><digtinfo><formname>Geographcal-Tagged Image File Format (GeoTIFF), or Joint Photographic Experts Group (JPEG)</formname></digtinfo><digtopt><grouping><onlinopt><computer><grouping><networka><networkr>https://glovis.usgs.gov</networkr><networkr>https://earthexplorer.usgs.gov</networkr></networka></grouping></computer></onlinopt></grouping></digtopt></digform></grouping><fees>All Landsat data held in the USGS EROS archive are downloadable at no cost to all users.</fees><ordering>You may DOWNLOAD Landsat data online using EarthExplorer at http://earthexplorer.usgs.gov </ordering></stdorder><techpreq>Adequate computer capability is the only technical prerequisite for viewing data in digital form.&#xD;

<fgdc><metadata><idinfo><citation><citeinfo><origin>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</origin><pubdate>2013</pubdate><title>LANDSAT 8 OLI/TIRS Collection 1 - Path:  177 Row:  29 for Scene:  LC08_L1GT_177029_20170109_20170311_01_T2</title><geoform>Remote-Sensing Image</geoform><pubinfo><pubplace>Sioux Falls, South Dakota, USA</pubplace><publish>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</publish></pubinfo><onlink>https://lta.cr.usgs.gov/L8</onlink></citeinfo></citation><descript><abstract>The USGS Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center archive holds data collected by the Landsat suite of satellites, beginning with Landsat 1 in 1972.  Landsat 8, launched February 11, 2013, is the latest Landsat sensor.</abstract><purpose>The Landsat archive provides a rich collection of information about the Earth's land surface.  Major characteristics of changes to the surface of the planet can be detected, measured, and analyzed using Landsat data.  The information obtainable from the historical and current Landsat data play a key role in studying surface changes through time.</purpose><supplinf>Landsat represents the world's longest continuously acquired collection of space-based moderate-resolution land remote sensing data.  As a joint initiative between the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) and the National Aeronautical Space Administration (NASA), the Landsat Project and the data it collects support government, commercial, industrial, civilian, military, and educational communities throughout the United States and world.  Landsat 8 Operational Land Imager (OLI)/Thermal Infrared Sensor (TIRS) Collection 1 provides a quality-controlled selection of radiometrically calibrated and consistently geolocated data; particular geodetic accuracy and error tolerances are specified to align pixels for time series analysis through the full Landsat record. (https://landsat.usgs.gov/landsat-collections)</supplinf></descript><timeperd><timeinfo><grouping><sngdate><caldate>20170109</caldate></sngdate><rngdates><begdate>Start of &#xD;
There are no restrictions regarding the use of Landsat data distributed by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), unless expressly identified prior to or at the time of receipt. For Landsat, we request the following statement be used: Data available from the U.S. Geological Survey. Please refer to https://lta.cr.usgs.gov/ee_help_data_citation for more information on data citation.&#xD;
</useconst><ptcontac><cntinfo><grouping><cntperp><cntper>custserv@usgs.gov</cntper><cntorg>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</cntorg></cntperp></grouping><cntpos>Customer Service Representative</cntpos><cntaddr><addrtype>Mailing and Physical Address</addrtype><address>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center 47914 252nd Street</address><city>Sioux Falls</city><state>SD</state><postal>57198-0001</postal><country>USA</country></cntaddr><cntemail>custserv@usgs.gov</cntemail><hours>0800 - 1600 CT, M-F, -6 h GMT</hours><cntinst>custserv@usgs.gov</cntinst></cntinfo></ptcontac><browse><browsen>Browse graphic for:  http://earthexplorer.usgs.gov/browse/landsat_8/browse/full/landsat_8/LC08_L1GT_177029_20170109_20170311_01_T2</browsen><browsed>This is a compressed and resampled version of the Landsat image to help validate area of interest, data quality, and the impact of cloud cover, if it exists.</browsed><browset>JPEG</browset></browse><datacred>The Landsat Program, as defined by Congress in 1992 and amended by Presidential Decision Directive/NSTC-3 in May 1994, is managed cooperatively by the NASA and the USGS.  Responsibility for construction of the spacecraft and instrument lies with NASA.  The Landsat Program is part of NASA's Earth Observing System, a global change initiative administered by NASA's Earth Science Enterprise.  Data processing, archiving, and distribution are performed by the USGS.  The primary ground station, the data handling facility and archive are located at the USGS Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center in Sioux Falls, SD.  NASA managed flight operations from the control center at the Goddard Space Flight Center until October 1, 2000, at which time responsibility for flight operations transferred to the USGS.  The ground system is able to distribute Landsat 8 OLI/TIR data within 24 hours of its reception at the EROS.  The following statement should be used when citing, copying, or reprinting Landsat imagery or data: Data available from the U.S. Geological Survey.  The USGS Visual Identity System Guidance webpage ("Acknowledging or Crediting USGS as Information Source") provides additional details:  https://www2.usgs.gov/visual-id/credit_usgs.html.</datacred><secinfo><secsys>None</secsys><secclass>Unclassified</secclass><sechandl>None</sechandl></secinfo><native>Oracle</native><crossref><citeinfo><origin>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</origin><pubdate>20060510</pubdate><title>Landsat 8 OLI/TIRS Collection 1</title><geoform>Remote-Sensing Image</geoform><pubinfo><pubplace>Sioux Falls, South Dakota, USA</pubplace><publish>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</publish></pubinfo><onlink>https://earthexplorer.usgs.gov</onlink></citeinfo></crossref></idinfo><dataqual><attracc><attraccr>The identification of features is provided by the distinct electromagnetic energy it emits, reflects, or otherwise transmits, this is called the spectral signature. The USGS Visual Identity System Guidance webpage ("Acknowledging or Crediting USGS as Information Source") provides additional details:  https://www2.usgs.gov/visual-id/credit_usgs.html.</datacred><secinfo><secsys>None</secsys><secclass>Unclassified</secclass><sechandl>None</sechandl></secinfo><native>Oracle</native><crossref><citeinfo><origin>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</origin><pubdate>20060510</pubdate><title>Landsat 8 OLI/TIRS Collection 1</title><geoform>Remote-Sensing Image</geoform><pubinfo><pubplace>Sioux Falls, South Dakota, USA</pubplace><publish>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</publish></pubinfo><onlink>https://earthexplorer.usgs.gov</onlink></citeinfo></crossref></idinfo><dataqual><attracc><attraccr>The identification of features is provided by the distinct electromagnetic energy it emits, reflects, or otherwise transmits, this is called the spectral signature.  Other signatures such as tone (lightness or darkness), texture (surface roughness or smoothness), pattern, shadow, shape, and size are just as important.  Thus, through the use of the Operational Land Imager (OLI)  sensor, such elements as water features, soils, and vegetation can be identified and distinguished from each other.</attraccr></attracc><logic>N/A</logic><complete>The Landsat satellites circle the Earth on a sun-synchronous, near-polar orbit imaging the same 185 km (115 miles) ground swath every 16 days.</complete><posacc><horizpa><horizpar>L8 Level-1 systematic products meet the system requirement of 65 meters at a circular error with 90 percent confidence (CE90) horizontal accuracy.</horizpar></horizpa></posacc><lineage><procstep><procdesc>Landsat standard data products are processed using the Level-1 Product Generation System (LPGS), and are processed to the best level of correction possible (Level-1TP = Precision Terrain correction).  If full terrain correction is not possible, the data is processed to Level-1GS (Systematic) or Level-1GT (Systematic Terrain) correction.  Processing details can be found on http://landsat.usgs.gov/landsat-processing-details.  All Landsat 8 Level-1 Collection 1 data have been reprocessed and organized by a tiered inventory structure.  During Collection 1 reprocessing, all Landsat scenes in the USGS archive are assigned to a specific "Tier" based on data quality and level of processing.  If Tier 1 correction is not possible, the data is assigned to Tier 2.  Processing details can be found at https://landsat.usgs.gov/landsat-collections.</procdesc><procdate>20161030</procdate><proccont><cntinfo><grouping><cntperp><cntper>custserv@usgs.gov</cntper><cntorg>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</cntorg></cntperp></grouping><cntpos>Customer Service Representative</cntpos><cntaddr><addrtype>Mailing and Physical Address</addrtype><address>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center 47914 252nd Street</address><city>Sioux Falls</city><state>SD</state><postal>57198-0001</postal><country>USA</country></cntaddr><cntemail>custserv@usgs.gov</cntemail><hours>0800 - 1600 CT, M - F, -6 GMT</hours><cntinst>custserv@usgs.gov</cntinst></cntinfo></proccont></procstep></lineage><cloud></cloud></dataqual><spdoinfo><indspref>Landsat 8 collects data at 30-meter resolution (Panchromatic band 8 at 15 meters; thermal at 100 meters) </indspref><grouping><direct>Raster</direct><grouping><rastinfo><rasttype>Pixel</rasttype></rastinfo></grouping></grouping></spdoinfo><distinfo><grouping><distrib><cntinfo><grouping><cntperp><cntper>custserv@usgs.gov</cntper><cntorg>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</cntorg></cntperp></grouping><cntpos>Customer Service Representative</cntpos><cntaddr><addrtype>Mailing and Physical Address</addrtype><address>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center 47914 252nd Street</address><city>Sioux Falls</city><state>SD</state><postal>57198-0001</postal><country>USA</country></cntaddr><cntemail>custserv@usgs.gov</cntemail><hours>0800 - 1600 CT, M-F, -6 h GMT</hours><cntinst>custserv@usgs.gov</cntinst></cntinfo></distrib><distliab>Although these data have been processed successfully on a computer system at the USGS, no warranty expressed or implied is made by the USGS regarding the use of the data on any other system, nor does the act of distribution constitute any such warranty.</distliab><stdorder><grouping><digform><digtinfo><formname>Geographcal-Tagged Image File Format (GeoTIFF), or Joint Photographic Experts Group (JPEG)</formname></digtinfo><digtopt><grouping><onlinopt><computer><grouping><networka><networkr>https://glovis.usgs.gov</networkr><networkr>https://earthexplorer.usgs.gov</networkr></networka></grouping></computer></onlinopt></grouping></digtopt></digform></grouping><fees>All Landsat data held in the USGS EROS archive are downloadable at no cost to all users.</fees><ordering>You may DOWNLOAD Landsat data online using EarthExplorer at http://earthexplorer.usgs.gov </ordering></stdorder><techpreq>Adequate computer capability is the only technical prerequisite for viewing data in digital form.&#xD;

<fgdc><metadata><idinfo><citation><citeinfo><origin>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</origin><pubdate>2013</pubdate><title>LANDSAT 8 OLI/TIRS Collection 1 - Path:  178 Row:  28 for Scene:  LC08_L1GT_178028_20161231_20170314_01_T2</title><geoform>Remote-Sensing Image</geoform><pubinfo><pubplace>Sioux Falls, South Dakota, USA</pubplace><publish>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</publish></pubinfo><onlink>https://lta.cr.usgs.gov/L8</onlink></citeinfo></citation><descript><abstract>The USGS Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center archive holds data collected by the Landsat suite of satellites, beginning with Landsat 1 in 1972.  Landsat 8, launched February 11, 2013, is the latest Landsat sensor.</abstract><purpose>The Landsat archive provides a rich collection of information about the Earth's land surface.  Major characteristics of changes to the surface of the planet can be detected, measured, and analyzed using Landsat data.  The information obtainable from the historical and current Landsat data play a key role in studying surface changes through time.</purpose><supplinf>Landsat represents the world's longest continuously acquired collection of space-based moderate-resolution land remote sensing data.  As a joint initiative between the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) and the National Aeronautical Space Administration (NASA), the Landsat Project and the data it collects support government, commercial, industrial, civilian, military, and educational communities throughout the United States and world.  Landsat 8 Operational Land Imager (OLI)/Thermal Infrared Sensor (TIRS) Collection 1 provides a quality-controlled selection of radiometrically calibrated and consistently geolocated data; particular geodetic accuracy and error tolerances are specified to align pixels for time series analysis through the full Landsat record. (https://landsat.usgs.gov/landsat-collections)</supplinf></descript><timeperd><timeinfo><grouping><sngdate><caldate>20161231</caldate></sngdate><rngdates><begdate>Start of &#xD;
There are no restrictions regarding the use of Landsat data distributed by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), unless expressly identified prior to or at the time of receipt. For Landsat, we request the following statement be used: Data available from the U.S. Geological Survey. Please refer to https://lta.cr.usgs.gov/ee_help_data_citation for more information on data citation.&#xD;
</useconst><ptcontac><cntinfo><grouping><cntperp><cntper>custserv@usgs.gov</cntper><cntorg>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</cntorg></cntperp></grouping><cntpos>Customer Service Representative</cntpos><cntaddr><addrtype>Mailing and Physical Address</addrtype><address>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center 47914 252nd Street</address><city>Sioux Falls</city><state>SD</state><postal>57198-0001</postal><country>USA</country></cntaddr><cntemail>custserv@usgs.gov</cntemail><hours>0800 - 1600 CT, M-F, -6 h GMT</hours><cntinst>custserv@usgs.gov</cntinst></cntinfo></ptcontac><browse><browsen>Browse graphic for:  http://earthexplorer.usgs.gov/browse/landsat_8/browse/full/landsat_8/LC08_L1GT_178028_20161231_20170314_01_T2</browsen><browsed>This is a compressed and resampled version of the Landsat image to help validate area of interest, data quality, and the impact of cloud cover, if it exists.</browsed><browset>JPEG</browset></browse><datacred>The Landsat Program, as defined by Congress in 1992 and amended by Presidential Decision Directive/NSTC-3 in May 1994, is managed cooperatively by the NASA and the USGS.  Responsibility for construction of the spacecraft and instrument lies with NASA.  The Landsat Program is part of NASA's Earth Observing System, a global change initiative administered by NASA's Earth Science Enterprise.  Data processing, archiving, and distribution are performed by the USGS.  The primary ground station, the data handling facility and archive are located at the USGS Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center in Sioux Falls, SD.  NASA managed flight operations from the control center at the Goddard Space Flight Center until October 1, 2000, at which time responsibility for flight operations transferred to the USGS.  The ground system is able to distribute Landsat 8 OLI/TIR data within 24 hours of its reception at the EROS.  The following statement should be used when citing, copying, or reprinting Landsat imagery or data: Data available from the U.S. Geological Survey.  The USGS Visual Identity System Guidance webpage ("Acknowledging or Crediting USGS as Information Source") provides additional details:  https://www2.usgs.gov/visual-id/credit_usgs.html.</datacred><secinfo><secsys>None</secsys><secclass>Unclassified</secclass><sechandl>None</sechandl></secinfo><native>Oracle</native><crossref><citeinfo><origin>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</origin><pubdate>20060510</pubdate><title>Landsat 8 OLI/TIRS Collection 1</title><geoform>Remote-Sensing Image</geoform><pubinfo><pubplace>Sioux Falls, South Dakota, USA</pubplace><publish>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</publish></pubinfo><onlink>https://earthexplorer.usgs.gov</onlink></citeinfo></crossref></idinfo><dataqual><attracc><attraccr>The identification of features is provided by the distinct electromagnetic energy it emits, reflects, or otherwise transmits, this is called the spectral signature. The USGS Visual Identity System Guidance webpage ("Acknowledging or Crediting USGS as Information Source") provides additional details:  https://www2.usgs.gov/visual-id/credit_usgs.html.</datacred><secinfo><secsys>None</secsys><secclass>Unclassified</secclass><sechandl>None</sechandl></secinfo><native>Oracle</native><crossref><citeinfo><origin>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</origin><pubdate>20060510</pubdate><title>Landsat 8 OLI/TIRS Collection 1</title><geoform>Remote-Sensing Image</geoform><pubinfo><pubplace>Sioux Falls, South Dakota, USA</pubplace><publish>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</publish></pubinfo><onlink>https://earthexplorer.usgs.gov</onlink></citeinfo></crossref></idinfo><dataqual><attracc><attraccr>The identification of features is provided by the distinct electromagnetic energy it emits, reflects, or otherwise transmits, this is called the spectral signature.  Other signatures such as tone (lightness or darkness), texture (surface roughness or smoothness), pattern, shadow, shape, and size are just as important.  Thus, through the use of the Operational Land Imager (OLI)  sensor, such elements as water features, soils, and vegetation can be identified and distinguished from each other.</attraccr></attracc><logic>N/A</logic><complete>The Landsat satellites circle the Earth on a sun-synchronous, near-polar orbit imaging the same 185 km (115 miles) ground swath every 16 days.</complete><posacc><horizpa><horizpar>L8 Level-1 systematic products meet the system requirement of 65 meters at a circular error with 90 percent confidence (CE90) horizontal accuracy.</horizpar></horizpa></posacc><lineage><procstep><procdesc>Landsat standard data products are processed using the Level-1 Product Generation System (LPGS), and are processed to the best level of correction possible (Level-1TP = Precision Terrain correction).  If full terrain correction is not possible, the data is processed to Level-1GS (Systematic) or Level-1GT (Systematic Terrain) correction.  Processing details can be found on http://landsat.usgs.gov/landsat-processing-details.  All Landsat 8 Level-1 Collection 1 data have been reprocessed and organized by a tiered inventory structure.  During Collection 1 reprocessing, all Landsat scenes in the USGS archive are assigned to a specific "Tier" based on data quality and level of processing.  If Tier 1 correction is not possible, the data is assigned to Tier 2.  Processing details can be found at https://landsat.usgs.gov/landsat-collections.</procdesc><procdate>20161030</procdate><proccont><cntinfo><grouping><cntperp><cntper>custserv@usgs.gov</cntper><cntorg>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</cntorg></cntperp></grouping><cntpos>Customer Service Representative</cntpos><cntaddr><addrtype>Mailing and Physical Address</addrtype><address>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center 47914 252nd Street</address><city>Sioux Falls</city><state>SD</state><postal>57198-0001</postal><country>USA</country></cntaddr><cntemail>custserv@usgs.gov</cntemail><hours>0800 - 1600 CT, M - F, -6 GMT</hours><cntinst>custserv@usgs.gov</cntinst></cntinfo></proccont></procstep></lineage><cloud></cloud></dataqual><spdoinfo><indspref>Landsat 8 collects data at 30-meter resolution (Panchromatic band 8 at 15 meters; thermal at 100 meters) </indspref><grouping><direct>Raster</direct><grouping><rastinfo><rasttype>Pixel</rasttype></rastinfo></grouping></grouping></spdoinfo><distinfo><grouping><distrib><cntinfo><grouping><cntperp><cntper>custserv@usgs.gov</cntper><cntorg>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</cntorg></cntperp></grouping><cntpos>Customer Service Representative</cntpos><cntaddr><addrtype>Mailing and Physical Address</addrtype><address>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center 47914 252nd Street</address><city>Sioux Falls</city><state>SD</state><postal>57198-0001</postal><country>USA</country></cntaddr><cntemail>custserv@usgs.gov</cntemail><hours>0800 - 1600 CT, M-F, -6 h GMT</hours><cntinst>custserv@usgs.gov</cntinst></cntinfo></distrib><distliab>Although these data have been processed successfully on a computer system at the USGS, no warranty expressed or implied is made by the USGS regarding the use of the data on any other system, nor does the act of distribution constitute any such warranty.</distliab><stdorder><grouping><digform><digtinfo><formname>Geographcal-Tagged Image File Format (GeoTIFF), or Joint Photographic Experts Group (JPEG)</formname></digtinfo><digtopt><grouping><onlinopt><computer><grouping><networka><networkr>https://glovis.usgs.gov</networkr><networkr>https://earthexplorer.usgs.gov</networkr></networka></grouping></computer></onlinopt></grouping></digtopt></digform></grouping><fees>All Landsat data held in the USGS EROS archive are downloadable at no cost to all users.</fees><ordering>You may DOWNLOAD Landsat data online using EarthExplorer at http://earthexplorer.usgs.gov </ordering></stdorder><techpreq>Adequate computer capability is the only technical prerequisite for viewing data in digital form.&#xD;

<fgdc><metadata><idinfo><citation><citeinfo><origin>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</origin><pubdate>2013</pubdate><title>LANDSAT 8 OLI/TIRS Collection 1 - Path:  177 Row:  29 for Scene:  LC08_L1TP_177029_20161224_20170315_01_T1</title><geoform>Remote-Sensing Image</geoform><pubinfo><pubplace>Sioux Falls, South Dakota, USA</pubplace><publish>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</publish></pubinfo><onlink>https://lta.cr.usgs.gov/L8</onlink></citeinfo></citation><descript><abstract>The USGS Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center archive holds data collected by the Landsat suite of satellites, beginning with Landsat 1 in 1972.  Landsat 8, launched February 11, 2013, is the latest Landsat sensor.</abstract><purpose>The Landsat archive provides a rich collection of information about the Earth's land surface.  Major characteristics of changes to the surface of the planet can be detected, measured, and analyzed using Landsat data.  The information obtainable from the historical and current Landsat data play a key role in studying surface changes through time.</purpose><supplinf>Landsat represents the world's longest continuously acquired collection of space-based moderate-resolution land remote sensing data.  As a joint initiative between the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) and the National Aeronautical Space Administration (NASA), the Landsat Project and the data it collects support government, commercial, industrial, civilian, military, and educational communities throughout the United States and world.  Landsat 8 Operational Land Imager (OLI)/Thermal Infrared Sensor (TIRS) Collection 1 provides a quality-controlled selection of radiometrically calibrated and consistently geolocated data; particular geodetic accuracy and error tolerances are specified to align pixels for time series analysis through the full Landsat record. (https://landsat.usgs.gov/landsat-collections)</supplinf></descript><timeperd><timeinfo><grouping><sngdate><caldate>20161224</caldate></sngdate><rngdates><begdate>Start of &#xD;
There are no restrictions regarding the use of Landsat data distributed by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), unless expressly identified prior to or at the time of receipt. For Landsat, we request the following statement be used: Data available from the U.S. Geological Survey. Please refer to https://lta.cr.usgs.gov/ee_help_data_citation for more information on data citation.&#xD;
</useconst><ptcontac><cntinfo><grouping><cntperp><cntper>custserv@usgs.gov</cntper><cntorg>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</cntorg></cntperp></grouping><cntpos>Customer Service Representative</cntpos><cntaddr><addrtype>Mailing and Physical Address</addrtype><address>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center 47914 252nd Street</address><city>Sioux Falls</city><state>SD</state><postal>57198-0001</postal><country>USA</country></cntaddr><cntemail>custserv@usgs.gov</cntemail><hours>0800 - 1600 CT, M-F, -6 h GMT</hours><cntinst>custserv@usgs.gov</cntinst></cntinfo></ptcontac><browse><browsen>Browse graphic for:  http://earthexplorer.usgs.gov/browse/landsat_8/browse/full/landsat_8/LC08_L1TP_177029_20161224_20170315_01_T1</browsen><browsed>This is a compressed and resampled version of the Landsat image to help validate area of interest, data quality, and the impact of cloud cover, if it exists.</browsed><browset>JPEG</browset></browse><datacred>The Landsat Program, as defined by Congress in 1992 and amended by Presidential Decision Directive/NSTC-3 in May 1994, is managed cooperatively by the NASA and the USGS.  Responsibility for construction of the spacecraft and instrument lies with NASA.  The Landsat Program is part of NASA's Earth Observing System, a global change initiative administered by NASA's Earth Science Enterprise.  Data processing, archiving, and distribution are performed by the USGS.  The primary ground station, the data handling facility and archive are located at the USGS Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center in Sioux Falls, SD.  NASA managed flight operations from the control center at the Goddard Space Flight Center until October 1, 2000, at which time responsibility for flight operations transferred to the USGS.  The ground system is able to distribute Landsat 8 OLI/TIR data within 24 hours of its reception at the EROS.  The following statement should be used when citing, copying, or reprinting Landsat imagery or data: Data available from the U.S. Geological Survey.  The USGS Visual Identity System Guidance webpage ("Acknowledging or Crediting USGS as Information Source") provides additional details:  https://www2.usgs.gov/visual-id/credit_usgs.html.</datacred><secinfo><secsys>None</secsys><secclass>Unclassified</secclass><sechandl>None</sechandl></secinfo><native>Oracle</native><crossref><citeinfo><origin>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</origin><pubdate>20060510</pubdate><title>Landsat 8 OLI/TIRS Collection 1</title><geoform>Remote-Sensing Image</geoform><pubinfo><pubplace>Sioux Falls, South Dakota, USA</pubplace><publish>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</publish></pubinfo><onlink>https://earthexplorer.usgs.gov</onlink></citeinfo></crossref></idinfo><dataqual><attracc><attraccr>The identification of features is provided by the distinct electromagnetic energy it emits, reflects, or otherwise transmits, this is called the spectral signature. The USGS Visual Identity System Guidance webpage ("Acknowledging or Crediting USGS as Information Source") provides additional details:  https://www2.usgs.gov/visual-id/credit_usgs.html.</datacred><secinfo><secsys>None</secsys><secclass>Unclassified</secclass><sechandl>None</sechandl></secinfo><native>Oracle</native><crossref><citeinfo><origin>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</origin><pubdate>20060510</pubdate><title>Landsat 8 OLI/TIRS Collection 1</title><geoform>Remote-Sensing Image</geoform><pubinfo><pubplace>Sioux Falls, South Dakota, USA</pubplace><publish>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</publish></pubinfo><onlink>https://earthexplorer.usgs.gov</onlink></citeinfo></crossref></idinfo><dataqual><attracc><attraccr>The identification of features is provided by the distinct electromagnetic energy it emits, reflects, or otherwise transmits, this is called the spectral signature.  Other signatures such as tone (lightness or darkness), texture (surface roughness or smoothness), pattern, shadow, shape, and size are just as important.  Thus, through the use of the Operational Land Imager (OLI)  sensor, such elements as water features, soils, and vegetation can be identified and distinguished from each other.</attraccr></attracc><logic>N/A</logic><complete>The Landsat satellites circle the Earth on a sun-synchronous, near-polar orbit imaging the same 185 km (115 miles) ground swath every 16 days.</complete><posacc><horizpa><horizpar>L8 Level-1 systematic products meet the system requirement of 65 meters at a circular error with 90 percent confidence (CE90) horizontal accuracy.</horizpar></horizpa></posacc><lineage><procstep><procdesc>Landsat standard data products are processed using the Level-1 Product Generation System (LPGS), and are processed to the best level of correction possible (Level-1TP = Precision Terrain correction).  If full terrain correction is not possible, the data is processed to Level-1GS (Systematic) or Level-1GT (Systematic Terrain) correction.  Processing details can be found on http://landsat.usgs.gov/landsat-processing-details.  All Landsat 8 Level-1 Collection 1 data have been reprocessed and organized by a tiered inventory structure.  During Collection 1 reprocessing, all Landsat scenes in the USGS archive are assigned to a specific "Tier" based on data quality and level of processing.  If Tier 1 correction is not possible, the data is assigned to Tier 2.  Processing details can be found at https://landsat.usgs.gov/landsat-collections.</procdesc><procdate>20161030</procdate><proccont><cntinfo><grouping><cntperp><cntper>custserv@usgs.gov</cntper><cntorg>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</cntorg></cntperp></grouping><cntpos>Customer Service Representative</cntpos><cntaddr><addrtype>Mailing and Physical Address</addrtype><address>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center 47914 252nd Street</address><city>Sioux Falls</city><state>SD</state><postal>57198-0001</postal><country>USA</country></cntaddr><cntemail>custserv@usgs.gov</cntemail><hours>0800 - 1600 CT, M - F, -6 GMT</hours><cntinst>custserv@usgs.gov</cntinst></cntinfo></proccont></procstep></lineage><cloud></cloud></dataqual><spdoinfo><indspref>Landsat 8 collects data at 30-meter resolution (Panchromatic band 8 at 15 meters; thermal at 100 meters) </indspref><grouping><direct>Raster</direct><grouping><rastinfo><rasttype>Pixel</rasttype></rastinfo></grouping></grouping></spdoinfo><distinfo><grouping><distrib><cntinfo><grouping><cntperp><cntper>custserv@usgs.gov</cntper><cntorg>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</cntorg></cntperp></grouping><cntpos>Customer Service Representative</cntpos><cntaddr><addrtype>Mailing and Physical Address</addrtype><address>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center 47914 252nd Street</address><city>Sioux Falls</city><state>SD</state><postal>57198-0001</postal><country>USA</country></cntaddr><cntemail>custserv@usgs.gov</cntemail><hours>0800 - 1600 CT, M-F, -6 h GMT</hours><cntinst>custserv@usgs.gov</cntinst></cntinfo></distrib><distliab>Although these data have been processed successfully on a computer system at the USGS, no warranty expressed or implied is made by the USGS regarding the use of the data on any other system, nor does the act of distribution constitute any such warranty.</distliab><stdorder><grouping><digform><digtinfo><formname>Geographcal-Tagged Image File Format (GeoTIFF), or Joint Photographic Experts Group (JPEG)</formname></digtinfo><digtopt><grouping><onlinopt><computer><grouping><networka><networkr>https://glovis.usgs.gov</networkr><networkr>https://earthexplorer.usgs.gov</networkr></networka></grouping></computer></onlinopt></grouping></digtopt></digform></grouping><fees>All Landsat data held in the USGS EROS archive are downloadable at no cost to all users.</fees><ordering>You may DOWNLOAD Landsat data online using EarthExplorer at http://earthexplorer.usgs.gov </ordering></stdorder><techpreq>Adequate computer capability is the only technical prerequisite for viewing data in digital form.&#xD;

<fgdc><metadata><idinfo><citation><citeinfo><origin>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</origin><pubdate>2013</pubdate><title>LANDSAT 8 OLI/TIRS Collection 1 - Path:  178 Row:  28 for Scene:  LC08_L1GT_178028_20161215_20170316_01_T2</title><geoform>Remote-Sensing Image</geoform><pubinfo><pubplace>Sioux Falls, South Dakota, USA</pubplace><publish>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</publish></pubinfo><onlink>https://lta.cr.usgs.gov/L8</onlink></citeinfo></citation><descript><abstract>The USGS Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center archive holds data collected by the Landsat suite of satellites, beginning with Landsat 1 in 1972.  Landsat 8, launched February 11, 2013, is the latest Landsat sensor.</abstract><purpose>The Landsat archive provides a rich collection of information about the Earth's land surface.  Major characteristics of changes to the surface of the planet can be detected, measured, and analyzed using Landsat data.  The information obtainable from the historical and current Landsat data play a key role in studying surface changes through time.</purpose><supplinf>Landsat represents the world's longest continuously acquired collection of space-based moderate-resolution land remote sensing data.  As a joint initiative between the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) and the National Aeronautical Space Administration (NASA), the Landsat Project and the data it collects support government, commercial, industrial, civilian, military, and educational communities throughout the United States and world.  Landsat 8 Operational Land Imager (OLI)/Thermal Infrared Sensor (TIRS) Collection 1 provides a quality-controlled selection of radiometrically calibrated and consistently geolocated data; particular geodetic accuracy and error tolerances are specified to align pixels for time series analysis through the full Landsat record. (https://landsat.usgs.gov/landsat-collections)</supplinf></descript><timeperd><timeinfo><grouping><sngdate><caldate>20161215</caldate></sngdate><rngdates><begdate>Start of &#xD;
There are no restrictions regarding the use of Landsat data distributed by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), unless expressly identified prior to or at the time of receipt. For Landsat, we request the following statement be used: Data available from the U.S. Geological Survey. Please refer to https://lta.cr.usgs.gov/ee_help_data_citation for more information on data citation.&#xD;
</useconst><ptcontac><cntinfo><grouping><cntperp><cntper>custserv@usgs.gov</cntper><cntorg>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</cntorg></cntperp></grouping><cntpos>Customer Service Representative</cntpos><cntaddr><addrtype>Mailing and Physical Address</addrtype><address>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center 47914 252nd Street</address><city>Sioux Falls</city><state>SD</state><postal>57198-0001</postal><country>USA</country></cntaddr><cntemail>custserv@usgs.gov</cntemail><hours>0800 - 1600 CT, M-F, -6 h GMT</hours><cntinst>custserv@usgs.gov</cntinst></cntinfo></ptcontac><browse><browsen>Browse graphic for:  http://earthexplorer.usgs.gov/browse/landsat_8/browse/full/landsat_8/LC08_L1GT_178028_20161215_20170316_01_T2</browsen><browsed>This is a compressed and resampled version of the Landsat image to help validate area of interest, data quality, and the impact of cloud cover, if it exists.</browsed><browset>JPEG</browset></browse><datacred>The Landsat Program, as defined by Congress in 1992 and amended by Presidential Decision Directive/NSTC-3 in May 1994, is managed cooperatively by the NASA and the USGS.  Responsibility for construction of the spacecraft and instrument lies with NASA.  The Landsat Program is part of NASA's Earth Observing System, a global change initiative administered by NASA's Earth Science Enterprise.  Data processing, archiving, and distribution are performed by the USGS.  The primary ground station, the data handling facility and archive are located at the USGS Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center in Sioux Falls, SD.  NASA managed flight operations from the control center at the Goddard Space Flight Center until October 1, 2000, at which time responsibility for flight operations transferred to the USGS.  The ground system is able to distribute Landsat 8 OLI/TIR data within 24 hours of its reception at the EROS.  The following statement should be used when citing, copying, or reprinting Landsat imagery or data: Data available from the U.S. Geological Survey.  The USGS Visual Identity System Guidance webpage ("Acknowledging or Crediting USGS as Information Source") provides additional details:  https://www2.usgs.gov/visual-id/credit_usgs.html.</datacred><secinfo><secsys>None</secsys><secclass>Unclassified</secclass><sechandl>None</sechandl></secinfo><native>Oracle</native><crossref><citeinfo><origin>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</origin><pubdate>20060510</pubdate><title>Landsat 8 OLI/TIRS Collection 1</title><geoform>Remote-Sensing Image</geoform><pubinfo><pubplace>Sioux Falls, South Dakota, USA</pubplace><publish>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</publish></pubinfo><onlink>https://earthexplorer.usgs.gov</onlink></citeinfo></crossref></idinfo><dataqual><attracc><attraccr>The identification of features is provided by the distinct electromagnetic energy it emits, reflects, or otherwise transmits, this is called the spectral signature. The USGS Visual Identity System Guidance webpage ("Acknowledging or Crediting USGS as Information Source") provides additional details:  https://www2.usgs.gov/visual-id/credit_usgs.html.</datacred><secinfo><secsys>None</secsys><secclass>Unclassified</secclass><sechandl>None</sechandl></secinfo><native>Oracle</native><crossref><citeinfo><origin>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</origin><pubdate>20060510</pubdate><title>Landsat 8 OLI/TIRS Collection 1</title><geoform>Remote-Sensing Image</geoform><pubinfo><pubplace>Sioux Falls, South Dakota, USA</pubplace><publish>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</publish></pubinfo><onlink>https://earthexplorer.usgs.gov</onlink></citeinfo></crossref></idinfo><dataqual><attracc><attraccr>The identification of features is provided by the distinct electromagnetic energy it emits, reflects, or otherwise transmits, this is called the spectral signature.  Other signatures such as tone (lightness or darkness), texture (surface roughness or smoothness), pattern, shadow, shape, and size are just as important.  Thus, through the use of the Operational Land Imager (OLI)  sensor, such elements as water features, soils, and vegetation can be identified and distinguished from each other.</attraccr></attracc><logic>N/A</logic><complete>The Landsat satellites circle the Earth on a sun-synchronous, near-polar orbit imaging the same 185 km (115 miles) ground swath every 16 days.</complete><posacc><horizpa><horizpar>L8 Level-1 systematic products meet the system requirement of 65 meters at a circular error with 90 percent confidence (CE90) horizontal accuracy.</horizpar></horizpa></posacc><lineage><procstep><procdesc>Landsat standard data products are processed using the Level-1 Product Generation System (LPGS), and are processed to the best level of correction possible (Level-1TP = Precision Terrain correction).  If full terrain correction is not possible, the data is processed to Level-1GS (Systematic) or Level-1GT (Systematic Terrain) correction.  Processing details can be found on http://landsat.usgs.gov/landsat-processing-details.  All Landsat 8 Level-1 Collection 1 data have been reprocessed and organized by a tiered inventory structure.  During Collection 1 reprocessing, all Landsat scenes in the USGS archive are assigned to a specific "Tier" based on data quality and level of processing.  If Tier 1 correction is not possible, the data is assigned to Tier 2.  Processing details can be found at https://landsat.usgs.gov/landsat-collections.</procdesc><procdate>20161030</procdate><proccont><cntinfo><grouping><cntperp><cntper>custserv@usgs.gov</cntper><cntorg>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</cntorg></cntperp></grouping><cntpos>Customer Service Representative</cntpos><cntaddr><addrtype>Mailing and Physical Address</addrtype><address>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center 47914 252nd Street</address><city>Sioux Falls</city><state>SD</state><postal>57198-0001</postal><country>USA</country></cntaddr><cntemail>custserv@usgs.gov</cntemail><hours>0800 - 1600 CT, M - F, -6 GMT</hours><cntinst>custserv@usgs.gov</cntinst></cntinfo></proccont></procstep></lineage><cloud></cloud></dataqual><spdoinfo><indspref>Landsat 8 collects data at 30-meter resolution (Panchromatic band 8 at 15 meters; thermal at 100 meters) </indspref><grouping><direct>Raster</direct><grouping><rastinfo><rasttype>Pixel</rasttype></rastinfo></grouping></grouping></spdoinfo><distinfo><grouping><distrib><cntinfo><grouping><cntperp><cntper>custserv@usgs.gov</cntper><cntorg>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</cntorg></cntperp></grouping><cntpos>Customer Service Representative</cntpos><cntaddr><addrtype>Mailing and Physical Address</addrtype><address>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center 47914 252nd Street</address><city>Sioux Falls</city><state>SD</state><postal>57198-0001</postal><country>USA</country></cntaddr><cntemail>custserv@usgs.gov</cntemail><hours>0800 - 1600 CT, M-F, -6 h GMT</hours><cntinst>custserv@usgs.gov</cntinst></cntinfo></distrib><distliab>Although these data have been processed successfully on a computer system at the USGS, no warranty expressed or implied is made by the USGS regarding the use of the data on any other system, nor does the act of distribution constitute any such warranty.</distliab><stdorder><grouping><digform><digtinfo><formname>Geographcal-Tagged Image File Format (GeoTIFF), or Joint Photographic Experts Group (JPEG)</formname></digtinfo><digtopt><grouping><onlinopt><computer><grouping><networka><networkr>https://glovis.usgs.gov</networkr><networkr>https://earthexplorer.usgs.gov</networkr></networka></grouping></computer></onlinopt></grouping></digtopt></digform></grouping><fees>All Landsat data held in the USGS EROS archive are downloadable at no cost to all users.</fees><ordering>You may DOWNLOAD Landsat data online using EarthExplorer at http://earthexplorer.usgs.gov </ordering></stdorder><techpreq>Adequate computer capability is the only technical prerequisite for viewing data in digital form.&#xD;

<fgdc><metadata><idinfo><citation><citeinfo><origin>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</origin><pubdate>2013</pubdate><title>LANDSAT 8 OLI/TIRS Collection 1 - Path:  177 Row:  29 for Scene:  LC08_L1TP_177029_20161208_20170317_01_T1</title><geoform>Remote-Sensing Image</geoform><pubinfo><pubplace>Sioux Falls, South Dakota, USA</pubplace><publish>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</publish></pubinfo><onlink>https://lta.cr.usgs.gov/L8</onlink></citeinfo></citation><descript><abstract>The USGS Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center archive holds data collected by the Landsat suite of satellites, beginning with Landsat 1 in 1972.  Landsat 8, launched February 11, 2013, is the latest Landsat sensor.</abstract><purpose>The Landsat archive provides a rich collection of information about the Earth's land surface.  Major characteristics of changes to the surface of the planet can be detected, measured, and analyzed using Landsat data.  The information obtainable from the historical and current Landsat data play a key role in studying surface changes through time.</purpose><supplinf>Landsat represents the world's longest continuously acquired collection of space-based moderate-resolution land remote sensing data.  As a joint initiative between the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) and the National Aeronautical Space Administration (NASA), the Landsat Project and the data it collects support government, commercial, industrial, civilian, military, and educational communities throughout the United States and world.  Landsat 8 Operational Land Imager (OLI)/Thermal Infrared Sensor (TIRS) Collection 1 provides a quality-controlled selection of radiometrically calibrated and consistently geolocated data; particular geodetic accuracy and error tolerances are specified to align pixels for time series analysis through the full Landsat record. (https://landsat.usgs.gov/landsat-collections)</supplinf></descript><timeperd><timeinfo><grouping><sngdate><caldate>20161208</caldate></sngdate><rngdates><begdate>Start of &#xD;
There are no restrictions regarding the use of Landsat data distributed by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), unless expressly identified prior to or at the time of receipt. For Landsat, we request the following statement be used: Data available from the U.S. Geological Survey. Please refer to https://lta.cr.usgs.gov/ee_help_data_citation for more information on data citation.&#xD;
</useconst><ptcontac><cntinfo><grouping><cntperp><cntper>custserv@usgs.gov</cntper><cntorg>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</cntorg></cntperp></grouping><cntpos>Customer Service Representative</cntpos><cntaddr><addrtype>Mailing and Physical Address</addrtype><address>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center 47914 252nd Street</address><city>Sioux Falls</city><state>SD</state><postal>57198-0001</postal><country>USA</country></cntaddr><cntemail>custserv@usgs.gov</cntemail><hours>0800 - 1600 CT, M-F, -6 h GMT</hours><cntinst>custserv@usgs.gov</cntinst></cntinfo></ptcontac><browse><browsen>Browse graphic for:  http://earthexplorer.usgs.gov/browse/landsat_8/browse/full/landsat_8/LC08_L1TP_177029_20161208_20170317_01_T1</browsen><browsed>This is a compressed and resampled version of the Landsat image to help validate area of interest, data quality, and the impact of cloud cover, if it exists.</browsed><browset>JPEG</browset></browse><datacred>The Landsat Program, as defined by Congress in 1992 and amended by Presidential Decision Directive/NSTC-3 in May 1994, is managed cooperatively by the NASA and the USGS.  Responsibility for construction of the spacecraft and instrument lies with NASA.  The Landsat Program is part of NASA's Earth Observing System, a global change initiative administered by NASA's Earth Science Enterprise.  Data processing, archiving, and distribution are performed by the USGS.  The primary ground station, the data handling facility and archive are located at the USGS Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center in Sioux Falls, SD.  NASA managed flight operations from the control center at the Goddard Space Flight Center until October 1, 2000, at which time responsibility for flight operations transferred to the USGS.  The ground system is able to distribute Landsat 8 OLI/TIR data within 24 hours of its reception at the EROS.  The following statement should be used when citing, copying, or reprinting Landsat imagery or data: Data available from the U.S. Geological Survey.  The USGS Visual Identity System Guidance webpage ("Acknowledging or Crediting USGS as Information Source") provides additional details:  https://www2.usgs.gov/visual-id/credit_usgs.html.</datacred><secinfo><secsys>None</secsys><secclass>Unclassified</secclass><sechandl>None</sechandl></secinfo><native>Oracle</native><crossref><citeinfo><origin>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</origin><pubdate>20060510</pubdate><title>Landsat 8 OLI/TIRS Collection 1</title><geoform>Remote-Sensing Image</geoform><pubinfo><pubplace>Sioux Falls, South Dakota, USA</pubplace><publish>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Earth Resources Observation and Science (EROS) Center</publish></pubinfo><onlink>https://earthexplorer.usgs.gov</onlink></citeinfo></crossref></idinfo><dataqual><attracc><attraccr>The identification of features is provided by the distinct electromagnetic energy it emits, reflects, or otherwise transmits, this is called the spectral signature.
